question: Who among the following was not associated with the formation of U.P. Kisan Sabha in February 1918? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Indra Narain Dwivedi
option_2: Gauri Shankar Misra
option_3: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_4: Madan Mohan Malviya
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Jawaharlal Nehru was not associated with the formation of the United Provinces Kisan Sabha in February 1918. Gauri Shankar Mishra and Indra Narayan Dwivedi set up the Kisan Sabha in Lucknow in 1918 in response to exploitation. Madan Mohan Malviya also supported their efforts.
  • The Kisan Sabha (Peasant Association) was a protest movement in Uttar Pradesh from 1919 to 1922 that involved many agricultural caste groups. By June 1919, the Kisan Sabha had 450 branches.

question: At which Congress Session was the Working Committee authorized to launch a programme of Civil Disobedience? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Bombay
option_2: Lahore
option_3: Lucknow
option_4: Tripuri
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Congress Working Committee was authorized to launch a program of civil disobedience at the Lahore session in 1929. The program included non-payment of taxes and asking members of legislatures to resign their seats.

Other decisions made at the 1929 Lahore session include:

1. Boycotting the Round Table Conference

2. Declaring complete independence as the aim of Congress

3. Jawaharlal Nehru being elected president of the Congress

4. Unfurling the newly adopted tricolour flag on December 31, 19295. Deciding January 26, 1930 as India’s Independence Day

question: In October 1920, who of the following headed a group of Indians gathered at Tashkent to set up a communist Party of India? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: H. K. Sarkar
option_2: P. C. Joshi
option_3: M. C. Chagla
option_4: M. N. Roy
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • M.N. Roy, Abani Mukharji, and others founded the Communist Party of India (CPI) in Tashkent in October 1920. Roy was the main organizer of the party, and he recruited young ex-Muhajir students from India. Roy and his wife, Evelyn Roy-Trent, played a key role in bringing Mohammad Shafiq, Mohammad Ali, and other ex Muhajirs into the party.

question: In which one of the following provinces was a Congress Ministry not formed under the Act of 1935? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Bihar
option_2: Madras
option_3: Orissa
option_4: Punjab
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

Punjab was one of the three provinces that did not have a Congress Ministry formed under the 1935 Act:

Punjab :

  • In the 1937 elections, the Unionist Party led by Sikander Hayat Khan won 67 seats out of 175, while the Congress secured 18 seats. The Unionists formed a coalition ministry in Punjab, with Sir Sikander Hyat Khan serving as the premier.

Bengal :

  • The Indian National Congress (INC) won a majority in all provinces except Bengal, Assam, Punjab, Sindh, and the NWFP.

Sindh :

  • The INC won a majority in all provinces except Bengal, Assam, Punjab, Sindh, and the NWFP. The 1935 Act mandated provincial elections in British India in the winter of 1936-37.
  • The INC emerged in power in eight provinces in the 1937 elections, forming ministries in 8 out of 11 provinces.

question: Where were the Ghadar revolutionaries, who became active during the outbreak of the World War I based? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Central America
option_2: North America
option_3: West America
option_4: South America
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Ghadar revolutionaries were primarily based in the United States, especially in San Francisco, Vancouver, and New York. They also had branches along the US Coast and in the far East.
  • The Ghadar revolutionaries, also known as the Ghadar Party, were inspired by anti colonialist and nationalist ideas. They were Punjabi immigrants who had settled in the US and Canada. The Ghadar Party’s goal was to overthrow British rule in India and establish a socialist republic.

Some key members of the Ghadar Party include:

1. Lala Har Dayal

2. Sant Baba Wasakha Singh Dadehar

3. Baba Jawala Singh

4. Santokh Singh

5. Sohan Singh Bhakna

6. Ras Behari Bose

  • The Ghadar Party was initially called the Pacific Coast Hindustan Association and was formed in the United States on July 15, 1913.
  • The Ghadar Party’s headquarters were located at 436 Hill St, San Francisco, California in the Yugantar Ashram building.
  • The Ghadar Party’s newspaper, Ghadar, was published to spread awareness about British rule in India. In 1915, the Ghadar Party organized a failed uprising in India.

question: What was Komagata Maru? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: A political party based in Taiwan
option_2: Peasant communist leader of China
option_3: A naval ship on voyage to Canada
option_4: A Chinese village where Mao Tse Tung began his Long march
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Komagata Maru incident occurred in 1914 when a group of people from British India attempted to immigrate to Canada on the Japanese steamship Komagata Maru. The ship carried 376 passengers, mostly Sikh immigrants. When the ship arrived in Vancouver, the Canadian government refused to allow the passengers to disembark. The government enforced strict immigration laws that targeted people from Asian countries.
  • The incident is considered a stain on the history of Canada and highlights the racist government policies of the time. When the ship reached Budge Budge in September 1914, the British police opened fire at the passengers. When it ended, 22 people were dead, including 16 passengers. More than 200 of the surviving passengers were imprisoned.
  • In 2013 the Budge Budge station was renamed as Komagata Maru Budge Budge station to commemorate the martyrs of the Komagata Maru incident.

question:
Consider the following statements: On the eve of the launch of Quit India Movement, Mahatma Gandhi............ (UPSC Prelims 2005)

1. asked the Government servants to resign.

2. asked the soldiers to leave their posts.

3. asked the Princes of the Princely States to accept the sovereignty of their own people.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 2 and 3
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Mahatma Gandhi asked the Princes of the Princely States to accept the sovereignty of their own people on the eve of the launch of the Quit India Movement.
  • The Quit India Movement was launched on August 8, 1942, by Mahatma Gandhi at the Bombay session of the All India Congress Committee. The movement demanded an end to British rule in India.
  • In his “Quit India” speech, Gandhi said, “We cannot evoke the true spirit of sacrifice and velour, so long as we are not free”. He also said, “I know the British Government will not be able to withhold freedom from us, when we have made enough self-sacrifice”.

The movement was organized in several princely states, including:

  • Mysore, Hyderabad, Baroda, Kathiawad States, Deccan States, Jamnagar, Indore, Nawanagar.

Some of Gandhi’s instructions for the movement included:

1. Government servants: Declare allegiance to Congress, but don’t resign

2. Soldiers: Don’t leave the army, but don’t time compatriots

3. Students: Confident students can leave studies

4. Peasants: Pay rent to anti-government Zamindars, but don’t pay rent to pro government Zamindars

5. Princes: Support the people and accept their sovereignty

6. People of the princely states: Support the ruler only if he is anti-government, and declare themselves part of the Indian nation

The movement had three phases:

1. First phase: Peaceful protests and nonviolent resistance, which were quickly suppressed by the British

2. Second phase: Focus shifted to the countryside, which saw a major peasant rebellion

3. Third phase: Urban revolt, marked by strikes, boycotts, and picketing

  • The movement also included boycotting the British government and rejecting transactions involving the government. The British arrested tens of thousands of leaders, keeping them imprisoned until 1945.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2005)

1. Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar founded the Bethune School at Calcutta with the main aim of encouraging education for women

2. Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay was the first graduate of the Calcutta University.

3. Keshav Chandra Sen’s campaign against Sati led to the enactment of a law to ban Sati by the then Governor General

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 2
option_3: 2 and 3
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar was a secretary of the Bethune School in Calcutta, which was established in 1849.The school’s main goal was to encourage women’s education.
  • Vidyasagar was a pioneer of higher education for women in India. He believed that education was the only way to improve women’s lives and eradicate social evils. He also advocated for widow remarriage and girls’ education, which led to the Hindu Widow Remarriage Act of 1856.
  • Vidyasagar also wrote several books, including Borno Porichoy, Upakramonika,and Byakaran Koumudi. Borno Porichoy, which translates to “introduction to the letter”, is still used as a textbook for learning the Bengali alphabet.
  • Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay was one of the first two people to graduate from the University of Calcutta. He was born on June 27, 1838, and was educated at Hooghly Mohsin College and Presidency College, Calcutta.
  • Chattopadhyay was a writer, poet, novelist, and journalist in the Bengali language. He was a deputy magistrate in the Indian civil service from 1858 until his retirement in 1891. He also obtained a law degree in 1869.
  • Chattopadhyay is known for writing India’s national anthem, “Vande Mataram”, which inspired revolutionaries during the Indian independence movement. He believed that India could only rise with the help of nationalism, and that English education alone could not revive Hindu society.
  • On December 4, 1829, Lord William Bentinck, the first Governor-General of British-ruled India, passed the Bengal Sati Regulation (Regulation XVII). The law made Sati illegal and punishable by law.
  • Bentinck served as Governor-General from 1828–1835. Bentinck also helped Raja Rammohan Roy suppress other social evils, such as child marriage, polygamy, and female infanticide.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2005)

1. In the First Round Table Conference Dr. Ambedkar demanded electorates for the depressed classes.

2. In the Poona Pact, special provisions for representation of the depressed people in the local bodies and civil services were made.

3. The Indian National Congress did not take part in the Third Round Table Conference

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 2 and 3
option_3: 1 and 3
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Dr. B. R. Ambedkar demanded a separate electorate for the Untouchables at the First Round Table Conference. The conference took place in London from November 12, 1930 to January 19, 1931.
  • The Poona Pact allocated 148 seats for the depressed classes in legislative assemblies, instead of the original 80. Ambedkar agreed to sign the pact, despite being in favor of communal awards.
  • The Poona Pact was negotiated by B.R. Ambedkar and Mahatma Gandhi on behalf of depressed classes and upper-caste Hindu leaders. The pact was signed in the Yerwada Central Jail, Poona on September 24, 1932, as a protest against a decision made by the British Government.
  • The Indian National Congress (INC) did not participate in the Third Round Table Conference because many INC leaders were imprisoned for their involvement in the civil disobedience movement. The INC’s leader, Mahatma Gandhi, was also a member of the Congress.
  • The Third Round Table Conference was held from November 17 to December 24, 1932. The conference was an attempt to resolve problems between Indian leaders and the British government, but disagreements between the two parties prevented the conferences from resolving the problems.
  • The Round Table Conferences were meetings between the British government and Indian representatives to ensure peace in British-occupied India. The conferences were held between 1930 and 1932.

question: Who among the following repealed the Vernacular Press Act? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Lord Dufferin
option_2: Lord Ripon
option_3: Lord Curzon
option_4: Lord Hardinge
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Lord Ripon repealed the Vernacular Press Act in 1881. The act was repealed on December 7, 1881, when Lord Ripon was Governor General and Viceroy of India.
  • The Vernacular Press Act of 1878 restricted the freedom of the press of Indian languages.
  • The act was strongly opposed by Indian journalists, intellectuals, and nationalist leaders, who saw it as a violation of press freedom and an attempt to silence dissent.
  • The resentment it produced among Indians became one of the catalysts giving rise to India’s growing independence movement.

question: Who among the following was a proponent of Fabianism as a movement? (UPSC Prelims 2005)
option_1: Annie Beasant
option_2: A. O. Hume
option_3: Michael Madhusudan Dutt
option_4: R. Palme Dutt
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Fabian Society is a British socialist organisation ‘whose purpose is to advance the principles of Democratic Socialism via gradualist and reformist effort in democracies, rather than the revolutionary overthrow.
  • Immediately upon its inception, the Fabian Society began attracting many prominent contemporary figures drawn to it’s socialist cause

Some early Fabianism theorists and members include:

1. George Bernard Shaw :

  • Shaw (1856-1950) is an early Fabian theorist and member of the Fabian Society. In 1889, Shaw edited a collection of essays called Fabian Essays in Socialism.

2. Sidney and Beatrice Webb :

  • The Webb brothers are at the core of the Fabian Society. They wrote studies on industrial Britain and alternative co operative economics.

3. Graham Wallas :

  • Wallas is an early Fabian theorist and member of the Fabian Society.

4. Annie Besant :

  • Besant is an early member of the Fabian Society.

5. Edward Pease :

  • Pease is an early member of the Fabian Society. Fabianism is a socialist organization that advocates for a gradual transition to a socialist society.

Fabianism advocates for:

1. A more equitable distribution of wealth

2. Social justice

3. Universal access to education

4. Elimination of poverty and inequality

5. Defense of democratic values 6. Empowerment of citizens

question: Who was the Governor-General of India during the Sepoy Mutiny? (UPSC Prelims 2006)
option_1: Lord Canning
option_2: Lord Dalhousie
option_3: Lord Hardinge
option_4: Lord Lytton
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Charles John Canning, also known as Lord Canning, was the Governor-General of India during the Indian Mutiny of 1857.
  • He became the first Viceroy of India in 1858 and served for four years until 1862.
  • During his tenure, Canning successfully suppressed the Mutiny of 1857. He also established the universities of Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras.

question: Which portfolio was held by Dr. Rajendra Prasad in the Interim Government formed in the year 1946? (UPSC Prelims 2006)
option_1: Defence
option_2: External Affairs and Commonwealth
option_3: Food and Agriculture
option_4: None
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Dr. Rajendra Prasad held the portfolio of Food and Agriculture in the Interim Government of India, formed in 1946.
  • The Interim Government was formed from the Constituent Assembly, which was elected in August 1946. The Indian National Congress (INC) won around 69% of the seats in the Constituent Assembly.
  • After India gained independence in 1947, Prasad was elected as President of the Constituent Assembly of India. He served as India’s first president from January 26, 1950, until May 13, 1962.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2006)

1. The Charter Act 1853 abolished East India Company’s monopoly of Indian trade

2. Under the Government of India Act, 1858, the British Parliament abolished the East India company altogether and undertook the responsibility of ruling India directly.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither I nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Charter Act of 1813 ended the East India Company’s commercial trade monopoly, except for trade with China and tea. The Charter Act of 1833 ended the company’s activities as a commercial body, and it became purely administrative. The Charter Act of 1853 renewed the company’s charter, but unlike previous charters, it did not specify a time period.
  • British Parliament passed the Government of India Act of 1858 to abolish the East India Company and take over the responsibility of ruling India.
  • The act was passed on August 2, 1858.The act transferred the East India Company’s government and territories to the British Crown. It also made Queen Victoria the administrative head of the colony of India and replaced the East India Company’s Court of Directors with a Secretary of State.
  • The East India Company was a joint-stock company founded in 1600 to trade in the Indian Ocean region. In 1833, the company lost its special trading privileges and the right to trade.

question:
Consider the following statements about Madam Bhikaji Cama............. (UPSC Prelims 2006)

1. Madam Cama unfurled the National Flag at the international Socialist Conference in Paris in the year 1907.

2 . Madam Cama served as private secretary to Dadabhai Naoroji 3. Madam Cama was born to Parsi parents.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1, 2 and 3
option_2: 2 and 3, only
option_3: 1 and 2, only
option_4: 3 only
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Madam Bhikaji Cama unfurled the first version of the Indian national flag at the International Socialist Congress in Stuttgart, Germany on August 22, 1907.
  • The flag was a tricolour of green, saffron, and red stripes.
  • Madam Bhikaji Cama (1861-1936) served as the private secretary to Dadabhai Naoroji, a prominent leader of the Indian National Congress. Naoroji was the first Asian to be elected to the British House of Commons.
  • Cama also supported the founding of Varma’s Indian Home Rule Society in 1905. She is also known for unfurling the first version of the Indian national flag at the International Socialist Conference inStuttgart, Germany in 1907. She is known as the “Mother of the Indian Revolution”.
  • Cama also started the Paris edition of Bande Mataram to spread information about the freedom movement and gain support. The newspaper’s purpose was to oppose British rule in India. Cama is known as the “Mother of the Indian Revolution”. She is believed to have designed the flag jointly with someone. During the flag-raising ceremony, she appealed for equality and autonomy from the British, who had taken over the Indian subcontinent. She also described the devastating effects of a famine that had struck the Indian subcontinent.
  • Madam Cama (1861-1936) was born to Parsi parents. Her parents were Sorabji Framji Patel and Jaijibai Sorabji Patel. Sorabji was a merchant and a lawyer who was a well-known member of the Parsi community.

question: With reference to the revolt of the year 1857, who of the following was betrayed by a friend; captured and put to death by the British? (UPSC Prelims 2006)
option_1: Nana Sahib
option_2: Kunwar Singh
option_3: Khan Bahadur Khan
option_4: Tantya Tope
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Tantia Tope was betrayed by a friend, captured, and put to death by the British in 1859. Tope was a general in the Rebellion and a close associate of Nana Sahib. In 1857, Tope was captured and killed by the British in the Paron forest while asleep in his camp.
  • Mansingh, a former Sardar in the Gwalior army and a feudatory of Scindia, betrayed Tope. The British government executed Tope by hanging on April 18, 1859 in Shivpuri.

question: In the year 1613, where was the English East India Company given permission to set up a factory (trading post)? (UPSC Prelims 2006)
option_1: Bangalore
option_2: Madras
option_3: Masulipattam
option_4: Surat
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • In 1613, the English East India Company was given permission to establish a factory in Surat by the Mughal Emperor Jahangir.
  • Surat is a port city in Gujarat, India, and at the time was a major center of trade. The British were interested in trading textiles, so they established the factory to facilitate trade with India.
  • The British East India Company’s first temporary factory was established in 1611 at Masulipatnam.

question: Under whose presidency was the Lahore Session of the Indian National Congress held in the year 1929 wherein a resolution was adopted to gain complete independence from the British? (UPSC Prelims 2006)
option_1: Bal Gangadhar Tilak
option_2: Gopal Krishna Gokhale
option_3: Jawaharlal Nehru
option_4: Motilal Nehru
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Jawaharlal Nehru was the president of the 1929 Lahore session of the Indian National Congress. On December 19, 1929, the Congress passed the historic “Purna Swaraj” resolution, which aims for complete independence from British rule. The session also decided on a civil disobedience movement for complete independence.

question: The song ‘Amar Sonar Bangla’ written during the Swadeshi Movement of India inspired the liberation struggle of Bangladesh. Who wrote this song? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Rajni Kanta Sen
option_2: Dwijendralal Ray
option_3: Mukunda Das
option_4: Rabindranath Tagore
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Rabindranath Tagore wrote the song “Amar Sonar Bangla” in 1905.The song was written during the first partition of Bengal by Lord Curzon.
  • The song inspired the liberation struggle of Bangladesh and was adopted as the country’s national anthem. The melody of the song was adopted from Gagan Harkara’s song “Ami Kothay Pabo Tare”.
  • Tagore also wrote the national anthem of India. He also influenced the words and music of the national anthem of Sri Lanka, “Sri Lanka Matha”.

question: Which one of the following aroused a wave of popular indignation that led to the massacre by the British at Jallianwala Bagh? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: The arms Act
option_2: The Public Safety Act
option_3: The Rowlatt Act
option_4: The Vernacular Press Act
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Rowlatt Act, also known as the Black Act, was the main reason for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre. The Rowlatt Act was passed on March 10, 1919, and extended wartime measures to increase the British government’s control over the common people. The act allows the government to imprison or confine anyone involved in seditious activities without a trial. The Rowlatt Act caused widespread anger and discontent among Indians, particularly in the Punjab region.
  • On April 13, 1919, a large crowd gathered in Jallianwala Bagh, an open space in Amritsar, to protest the Rowlatt Act and show support for arrested leaders. A British military officer, General Dyer, stationed a regiment of soldiers at the only entrance of the park and, without warning, ordered his soldiers to fire. The firing killed about 379 people and wounded about 1,200.

question: The first factory Act restricting the working hours of women and children, and authorizing local governments to make necessary rules was adopted during whose time? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Lord Lytton
option_2: Lord Bentinck
option_3: Lord Ripon
option_4: Lord Canning
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The first Factory Act in India was passed in 1881 during the tenure of Lord Ripon (1880-1884).

The act’s main goals were to:

1. Improve working conditions for laborers

2. Regulate the working hours of women and children in factories

3. Prohibit the employment of children under the age of seven

4. Mandate that dangerous machines be properly fenced to prevent any untoward incident

  • The act also includes a maximum of nine hours of work per day for children between the ages of 7-12, and prohibits the employment of children under the age of seven.
  • In 1875, a committee was appointed to investigate the conditions of factory work in the country. The committee favored some kind of legal restrictions in the form of factory laws. In 1885, a Factory Commission was appointed.

question: Who among the following started the newspaper Shome Prakash? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Dayanand Saraswati
option_2: Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar
option_3: Raja Rammohan Roy
option_4: Surendranath Banerjee
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar started the newspaper Shome Prakash in 1859. The weekly newspaper was published by the Sanskrit Press and edited by Dwarakanath Vidyabhushan. The newspaper is known for its role in the Indigo Movement. It became a leading Bengali newspaper, and some credit its success to its editor, Dwarkanath Vidyabhusan.
  • In 1878, the government suspended publication of Shom Prakash for a year after the vernacular press act. The newspaper reappeared in 19 April 1880 after providing written assurance of allegiance to the government.

question: At which one of the following Place did Mahatma Gandhi first start his Satyagraha in India? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Ahmedabad
option_2: Bardoli
option_3: Champaran
option_4: Kheda
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Mahatma Gandhi’s first Satyagraha movement was in 1917 in Champaran, Bihar. This farmer’s uprising is considered a historically important revolt in the Indian Independence Movement.
  • In 1918, Gandhi’s next Satyagraha was in the Kheda district of Gujarat, where he helped peasants struggling to pay taxes to the British government.
  • Satyagraha is Gandhi’s method of nonviolent resistance and civil disobedience. Methods of Satyagraha include fasting and economic boycotts.

question: Who among the following Europeans were the last to come to pre independence India as traders? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Dutch
option_2: English
option_3: French
option_4: Portuguese
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The French were the last European traders to arrive in India, in 1664. The FrenchEast India Company was established in 1664 by Louis XIV’s minister Colbert to compete with the Dutch and English East India Companies. In 1667, the French set up their first factory in Surat, and in 1668, they made their first settlement in Surat. Pondicherry became their headquarters in India.

question: The ruler of which one of the following States was removed from power by the British on the pretext of misgovernance? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Awadh
option_2: Jhansi
option_3: Nagpur
option_4: Satara
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • On February 7, 1856, Lord Dalhousie ordered the deposal of Wajid Ali Shah, the ruler of Awadh, on the basis of alleged internal misrule. The British annexed the Kingdom of Awadh in February 1856, in line with their Doctrine of Lapse. The Doctrine of Lapse states that the British would take over a kingdom if there was misrule.
  • Awadh is a region in the modern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. It was known as the United Provinces of Agra and Oudh before India’s independence. The annexation of Awadh was one of the reasons for the Revolt of 1857.

question: Which one of the following was the first fort constructed by the British in India? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Fort William
option_2: Fort St. George
option_3: Fort St. David
option_4: Fort St. Angelo
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Fort St. George, also known as White Town, is considered the first fort built by the British in India. It was built in 1639 1640 CE by the British East India Company in the coastal city of Chennai.
  • Fort St. George was originally a trading post for the British East India Company.The construction of the fort led to further settlements and trading activity in what was originally uninhabited land. The city may have evolved around the fortress.

Fort William :

  • It is a historical monument in Kolkata, India. It was built in 1696 by the British East India Company and is named after William III. The fort is located on the banks of the Hooghly River and is the headquarters of the Indian Army’s Eastern Command. The fort also houses the headquarters of the Indian Ordnance Factories. The fort is heavily guarded by the army and civilian entry is restricted.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2007)

1. Robert Clive was the first Governor General of Bengal.

2. William Bentinck was the first Governor General of India.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor General of Bengal, serving from 1772 1785. Hastings was also the first Governor of the Presidency of Fort William and the head of the Supreme Council of Bengal.
  • Hastings was an English statesman who ended the Dual Government system by enforcing the Regulating Act of 1773. The Dual System of Government gave the company the right to collect revenue, while the Nizam or Indian chiefs had administrative authority.
  • Lord William Bentinck was the first Governor-General of British India, serving from 1828–1835.

He is credited with several reforms, including:

1. Abolishing Sati

2. Suppressing Thugee, infanticide, and child sacrifices

3. Passing the English Education Act of 1835

4. Establishing the Medical College and Hospital in Kolkata

  • Lord Mountbatten was the first Governor General of the Dominion of India, serving from 1947–1948.

question: Which one of the following places was associated with Acharya Vinoba Bhave’s Bhoodan Movement at the beginning of the movement? (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Udaygiri
option_2: Rapur
option_3: Pochampalli
option_4: Venkatagiri
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Bhoodan Movement, also known as the Land Gift Movement or Bloodless Revolution, was started by Acharya Vinoba Bhave in 1951 at Pochampally, Telangana. The movement is a voluntary land reform movement that aims to redistribute land from landlords to landless farmers. Bhave took donated land from landowners and gave it to poor and landless people for them to cultivate.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2007)

1. Jawaharlal Nehru was in his fourth term as the Prime Minister of India at the time of his death

2. Jawaharlal Nehru represented Rae Bareilly constituency as a Member of Parliament.

3. The first non-Congress Prime Minister of India assumed the Office in the year 1977.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 and 2
option_2: 3 only
option_3: 1 only
option_4: 1 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Jawaharlal Nehru was in his fourth term as the Prime Minister of India when he died in 1964.
  • Nehru was the first prime minister of independent India, serving from 1947-1964. He was a major leader in the fight against British rule in India and won the first general elections in India. Nehru's premiership was the longest in India's history, lasting 16 years and 286 days.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru never represented Rae Bareilly.
  • In fact, he represented the Phulpur constituency in Uttar Pradesh in the Lok Sabha from 1952 until his death in 1964.
  • Shri Desai was himself selected to the Lok Sabha from the Surat Constituency in Gujarat. He was later unanimously elected as Leader of the Janata Party in Parliament and was sworn in as the Prime Minister of India on March 24, 1977.

Therefore the correct answer is (D) 1 and 3.

question:
Assertion (A) : According to the Wavell Plan, the number of Hindu and Muslim members in the Executive Council were to be equal.

Reason (R) : Wavell thought that this arrangement would have avoided the partition of India (UPSC Prelims 2007)
option_1: Both A and R are individually true and R is the correct explanation of A.
option_2: Both A and R are individually true but R is not the correct explanation of A
option_3: A is True but R is false
option_4: A is false but R is true
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The statement “Wavell thought that this arrangement would have avoided the partition of India” is incorrect.
  • In 1945, Lord Wavell came up with the Wavell Plan at the Simla Conference. The plan proposed that the Executive Council of the Viceroy would be made up of Indians, with the exception of the Viceroy and Commander-in-Chief. The council would also include “caste-Hindus”, Muslims, Depressed Classes, and Sikhs. The plan also proposed that the number of Hindu and Muslim members in the Executive Council would be equal.
  • The Wavell Plan was intended to remove political issues and constitutional deadlock, and to promote self-governance for Indians. However, the plan was not intended to unite Hindus and Muslims to avoid the partition of India.
  • However, the Wavell Plan was not accepted by both the Muslim League and the Congress. The Muslim League wanted the power of veto to any constitutional proposal which it believed was not in its interest. Congress also opposed this unreasonable demand.

question: Where was the First Session of the Indian National Congress held in December 1885? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Ahemdabad
option_2: Bombay
option_3: Calcutta
option_4: Delhi
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The first session of the Indian National Congress (INC) was held in Bombay from December 28–30, 1885. The session was attended by 72 delegates, including social reformers, journalists, and lawyers. The INC was established at Gokuldas Tejpal Sanskrit College in Bombay, with Womesh Chunder Bonnerjee of Calcutta elected as president.
  • The INC’s second session was held in Calcutta from December 27–30, 1886. The third session was held in Madras from December 27–30, 1887, and the fourth session was held in Allahabad from December 26–29, 1888.
  • The second session of the Indian National Congress was held in 1906 under the leadership of Dadabhai Naoroji. The number of delegates increased to 434. At the end of the session, the Congress decided to establish Provincial Congress Committees across the country.
  • The Indian National Congress (INC) and the All-India Muslim League (AIML) held their annual sessions in Lucknow in 1916 toform a joint alliance to gain independence from the British. The two parties signed the Lucknow Pact on December 29, 1916, with the INC session on December 26, 28, 29, and 30, 1916, and the AIML session on December 31, 1916.

question: Which one of the following was a journal brought out by Abul Kalam Azad? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Al Hilal
option_2: Comrade
option_3: The Indian Sociologist
option_4: Zamindar
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, an Indian Muslim independence activist and the first education minister of India, established the weekly Urdu-language journal Al-Hilal in 1912.
  • The word Al-Hilal translates to “The Crescent” in Urdu. Al-Hilal was used to criticize the British Raj in India and to support the Indian independence movement. The paper also encouraged Indian Muslims to join the movement.
  • Al-Hilal became very influential in the Muslim community for its anti-British stance.
